factoid: Prince Andrew was going to ask you.
Prince Andrew knows nothing except that it was all he could do to get here.
Nesvítski addressed someone as "my dear boy".
Nesvítski said it is terrible.
Nesvítski admitted being wrong to laugh at Mack.
Nesvítski said we are getting it worse still.
Nesvítski told someone to sit down and have something to eat.
The other adjutant told Prince Andrew that the other adjutant will not be able to find his baggage or anything else now.
The other adjutant told Prince Andrew that God only knows where his man Peter is.
Prince Andrew asked where the headquarters are.
The answer was that they are to spend the night in Znaim.
Nesvítski said he has all he needs packed for two horses.
Nesvítski said the packs are splendid and fit to cross the Bohemian mountains.
Nesvítski said it is a bad lookout, old fellow.
Nesvítski asked Prince Andrew what is the matter with him.
Nesvítski said Prince Andrew must be ill to shiver like that.
Nesvítski noticed Prince Andrew winced as if at an electric shock.
Prince Andrew replied that it is nothing.
Prince Andrew had just remembered his recent encounter with the doctor's wife and the convoy officer.
Prince Andrew asked what the commander in chief is doing here.
Nesvítski said that he can't make out at all.
Prince Andrew said that everything is abominable.
Prince Andrew went off to the house where the commander in chief was.
Prince Andrew passed by Kutúzov's carriage and the exhausted saddle horses of his suite, with their Cossacks who were talking loudly together.
Prince Andrew entered the passage.
Kutúzov was in the house with Prince Bagratión and Weyrother.
It was told that Kutúzov was in the house with Prince Bagratión and Weyrother.
Weyrother was the Austrian general who succeeded Schmidt.
Little Kozlóvski was squatting on his heels in front of a clerk in the passage.
The clerk, with cuffs turned up, was hastily writing at a tub turned bottom upwards.
Kozlóvski's face looked worn.
Kozlóvski had evidently not slept all night.
Kozlóvski glanced at Prince Andrew and did not nod to him.
Kozlóvski asked the clerk "Second line... have you written it?" while dictating.
Kozlóvski mentioned "The Kiev Grenadiers, Podolian...".
The clerk said "One can't write so fast, your honor," and glanced angrily and disrespectfully at Kozlóvski.
The sounds of Kutúzov's voice, excited and dissatisfied, came through the door, interrupted by another unfamiliar voice.

Prince Andrew felt that something important and disastrous was about to happen, based on the sounds of voices, Kozlóvski's inattentive look, the clerk's disrespectful manner, the clerk and Kozlóvski squatting near the commander in chief, and the noisy laughter of the Cossacks holding the horses near the window.
Prince Andrew turned to Kozlóvski with urgent questions.
Kozlóvski said "Immediately, Prince."
Kozlóvski said "Dispositions for Bagratión."
Prince Andrew asked "What about capitulation?"
Kozlóvski replied that nothing of the sort, and orders are issued for a battle.
Prince Andrew moved toward the door from whence voices were heard.
While Prince Andrew was about to open the door, the sounds ceased, the door opened, and Kutúzov with his eagle nose and puffy face appeared in the doorway.
Prince Andrew stood in front of Kutúzov.
Kutúzov's expression of a single sound eye showed he was preoccupied with thoughts and anxieties, oblivious of Prince Andrew's presence.
Kutúzov looked straight at his adjutant's face without recognizing him.
Kutúzov asked Kozlóvski "Well, have you finished?"
Kozlóvski replied "One moment, your excellency."
Bagratión, a gaunt middle-aged man of medium height with a firm, impassive face of Oriental type, came out after the commander in chief.
Prince Andrew repeated "I have the honor to present myself" rather loudly, and handed Kutúzov an envelope.
Kutúzov said "Ah, from Vienna? Very good. Later, later!"
Kutúzov went out into the porch with Bagratión.
Kutúzov said to Bagratión "Well, good‑by, Prince. My blessing, and may Christ be with you in your great endeavor!"
